an8.72:4.1: “A mendicant is faithful, but not ethical.
an8.72:4.2: So they’re incomplete in that respect,
an8.72:4.4: ‘How can I become faithful and ethical?’
an8.72:4.5: When the mendicant is faithful and ethical, they’re complete in that respect.
an8.72:5.1: A mendicant is faithful and ethical, but not learned. …
an8.72:5.4: they don’t teach Dharma to the assembly with assurance …
an8.72:5.5: they don’t have direct meditative experience of the peaceful liberations that are formless, transcending form …
an8.72:5.6: they don’t realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having achieved it with their own insight due to the end of defilements.
an8.72:5.7: So they’re incomplete in that respect,
an8.72:5.9: ‘How can I become faithful, ethical, and learned, a Dharma speaker, one who frequents assemblies, one who teaches Dharma to the assembly with assurance, one who gets the formless liberations, and one who lives having realized the end of defilements?’
an8.72:6.1: When they’re faithful, ethical, and learned, a Dharma speaker, one who frequents assemblies, one who teaches Dharma to the assembly with assurance, one who gets the formless liberations, and one who lives having realized the end of defilements,
an8.72:6.5: A mendicant who has these eight qualities is inspiring all around, and is complete in every aspect.”
